channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: U.K.'s Boris Johnson said he would step down as prime minister once a replacement is found, a process that could take months https://t.co/XTeO4ondq6
Boris Johnson will resign as U.K. prime minister, officials said, marking an inglorious end to one of the most tumultuous leaderships in modern British history https://t.co/GwHW8zP7XY
Apple is preparing a feature called Lockdown Mode, meant to secure its products against some of the world’s most sophisticated spyware https://t.co/h89UHmUE5i
Many Russian tanks have a design feature that leads them to explode on the battlefield. Watch how that vulnerability impacts Russia’s campaign in Ukraine. https://t.co/suBXkHQlUA
The “Georgia Guidestones,” a towering Stonehenge-like monument, was destroyed for safety reasons after it sustained heavy damage in an explosion Wednesday https://t.co/U21t3nVJQ9
New Yorkers have seen all kinds of unspeakable things in the city's waters. Until recently, most hadn't seen dolphins. https://t.co/eMgMOYR4vp

A federal judge in California threw out Trump-era changes to the Endangered Species Act, including one that allowed economic factors to be considered on whether to list a species as threatened or endangered https://t.co/VoYpt1JrLA

From @WSJopinion: The U.S. owes President Volodymyr Zelensky’s government a chance to win this war, on which Ukraine’s survival and the West’s security depend. We must give the Ukrainians what they need, when they need it, writes @BillGalston. https://t.co/SECxvHCfYH
Not long ago countries competed to secure Covid-19 vaccines. Now the governments and manufacturers are throwing out doses by the millions because of waning demand. https://t.co/hHpv6Phyvs

Brittney Griner’s best hope of getting out of Russian prison is likely a prisoner exchange. But the U.S. has long been wary of such exchanges—and the Justice Department reflexively opposes them. https://t.co/LRfBcx0EmH
The heads of the FBI and MI5 delivered a rare joint address warning of Chinese espionage on a massive scale https://t.co/qgmM2T44RF

Barely a month after emerging from a lockdown, Shanghai residents were reminded that their battle against Covid-19 isn’t over when authorities ordered a new round of mass testing for more than half the city’s districts https://t.co/N6gR6TdzU7

Breaking: Donald Trump's former White House counsel, Pat Cipollone, will testify before the Jan. 6 committee behind closed doors on Friday, according to people familiar with the agreement https://t.co/90kkHcFblV
By many measures, the economies of red states have bounced back from the pandemic faster than blue ones. Migration patterns help explain why. https://t.co/JMh1HZcsXK

Amazon agreed to add Grubhub to its Prime membership program in the U.S., in a deal that also gives the e-commerce giant the option to acquire a small stake in the delivery service https://t.co/w5jEGtkCWg

Lawyers from the U.S. firm Kobre & Kim have registered as foreign agents to represent Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, a rare example of an American firm willing to advise a prominent Russian oligarch since the full-scale invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/aU2xL3yTll

A special grand jury in Fulton County, Ga., is subpoenaing Rudy Giuliani and other advisers to former President Donald Trump, representing a new development in a Democratic county prosecutor’s investigation into efforts to overturn Georgia’s 2020 election https://t.co/Fy5PduwLrH
Italy is suffering its worst drought in decades and its longest river is at the lowest level since at least World War II https://t.co/tVR7V3QzIq
The Russian army in Ukraine is transforming Europe’s largest nuclear power plant into a military base overlooking an active front https://t.co/JPwGpdpX75

SAS became one of the first casualties during a chaotic recovery in air travel. The Scandinavian airline has filed for bankruptcy protection in the U.S., saying a move by about 1,000 of its pilots to go on strike would worsen its already fraught finances. https://t.co/UZOPzDQ4d6
Covid-19 reinfections may deal a less-harsh blow than initial ones, but each infection creates some new opportunity for the virus to damage your body, a new study found https://t.co/qBKqjGdM3r

Six of the Highland Park shooting victims have been identified as Katherine Goldstein, Irina McCarthy, Kevin McCarthy, Jacquelyn Sundheim, Stephen Straus, and Nicolas Toledo Zaragoza. A seventh victim was also confirmed Tuesday. https://t.co/xa7Xp1X8Au
The Biden administration sued Arizona, alleging the state violates federal law by requiring proof of citizenship to vote for president https://t.co/tJUjChDBQJ

Forty-six million people moved to a different ZIP Code in the year through February 2022. The states that gained the most, led by Florida, Texas and North Carolina, are almost all red. https://t.co/oJ9Vkg7EOS

A federal judge in California threw out Trump-era changes to the Endangered Species Act, including one that allowed economic factors to be considered on whether to list a species as threatened or endangered https://t.co/IkDwAjFaEI

From @WSJopinion: Business leaders have chalked up Biden’s attacks on oil companies to political cynicism, but maybe they’re too generous. His tweet ordering gas stations to lower prices betrayed a willful ignorance about the private economy. https://t.co/AOLz8XUkRg
Ukrainian mathematician Maryna Viazovska became the second woman to earn the Fields Medal, an award considered mathematics’ equivalent of the Nobel Prize https://t.co/dTzRLdMse7

From @WSJopinion: Why the rush for toddler vaccines? Covid was clearly a health emergency for adults in 2020. By contrast, the urgency now feels political, writes @AllysiaFinley. https://t.co/9urSt8QJG4

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson suffered a serious political blow as two of his most senior ministers resigned, saying they no longer had confidence in his leadership. The departures will test his ability to retain power. https://t.co/XqXv7m4KMz
By many measures, the economies of red states have bounced back from the pandemic faster than blue ones. Migration patterns help explain why. https://t.co/g4SY3zsyv5

In the coming weeks, the Jan. 6 committee is expected to zero in on two overlapping areas of its probe: the extremist groups that participated in the attack and a minute-by-minute account of what took place inside the White House that day. https://t.co/dx71hIUVqZ
Americans are dipping into the huge pile of savings they accumulated over the first two years of the pandemic https://t.co/4PT7vgF9QA
The Ukraine war is driving a modernization of NATO weaponry, honing the alliance’s ability to face off against Russia. https://t.co/MWzci2FaUd
WNBA star Brittney Griner, on trial in Russia on drug charges, made a direct plea to President Biden to work to free her https://t.co/VKdIrdNDzs

Danish police said the mass shooting at a shopping mall in Copenhagen that left three people dead on Sunday wasn’t related to terrorism. The police haven’t so far disclosed a motive for the attack. https://t.co/g0hhumg3ZE
Stressed out? Sleep deprived? Sad? You may need a good cry. These steps will help you make the most of tears. https://t.co/Ogz59InpDC
Three years ago, Anna Weyant’s drawings were selling for $400 on the beach. Now the 27-year-old is an art star whose paintings sold for nearly $4 million combined at auction. https://t.co/FnljuTlpwI
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/J6NqO07voe

President Biden said in a Fourth of July address that many Americans are worried about the divisions roiling the nation but that the country had the power to choose a “unity of purpose” https://t.co/55I6wReHEg
Update: A person of interest in a July Fourth mass shooting at a parade in a Chicago suburb was apprehended by police following a brief pursuit https://t.co/HIzflDkBNk
President Biden is expected to soften tariffs on Chinese imports soon, amid a quandary over how to ease inflation while still looking tough on Beijing https://t.co/55WtIK7JhI
The U.S. and its allies are studying the conflict with Russia over Ukraine to distill lessons. "You can’t cyber your way across a river." https://t.co/eIsE0PhVew

Women’s basketball star Brittney Griner made a direct plea to President Biden to work to free her and other Americans detained abroad, in a handwritten letter delivered to the White House https://t.co/w4iEguuAEr
A 44-acre private island in Alaska is hitting the market for $20 million https://t.co/7Rbr8EMaZg
Update: A 22-year-old man who is still at large was identified as a person of interest in a deadly shooting at a July 4 parade in a Chicago suburb, police said https://t.co/omoauhLx7v

In Moscow, bars are packed, festivals are sold out and the police are busier handing out fines for public drinking than putting down dissent. “I haven’t had this much work since before the pandemic,” a DJ says. https://t.co/zWHpOlkXKW
Inflation-protected U.S. savings bonds are yielding an eye-popping 9.62%—if you can fight through the red tape to actually buy one https://t.co/8Zx8zWwTcS
Akron declared a state of emergency and set a 9 p.m. curfew after protests over the fatal police shooting of Jayland Walker, a 25-year-old Black man https://t.co/Kj4NHQOHEz
At least five people were killed in a shooting at a Fourth of July parade in the Chicago suburb of Highland Park, Ill. The suspect remains at large. https://t.co/IgSlJB58KI
The term "bear market" has a history going back centuries, to an old proverb warning against acting prematurely: “Don’t sell the bearskin before you’ve caught the bear.” https://t.co/sVLn4lqkMc
